Having a *force* option would work. ðŸ‘

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/cli/go-whisk-cli/commands/rule.go#L389
Seems sensible :) Agree to skip PG since this isn't tested anyway?

@jthomas is going to adapt the npm package to accept a fully qualified action name. I will bump the npm package version when a new release is out. I've also submitted a pr to that repo that renames the props to use `_` consistently.

Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/8efa1f96876af05f25f7e7ea2a5dace5bcac3054. 

Thank you for the fix and contribution.

:+1: reviewed up to d96fe1d.

We should ensure that the invoker will always include the "main" metadata on `init` and shift the "main" defined check there (although defensively coding against it in the action runner/proxy is ok).
Squashed and merged as dbbdc3b
This is old code, let's close this one so there is no confusion
running pg2#631

@ioana-blue repurposed this issue beyond the fix in #1477.
In particular, the behavior of `blocking [+ result]` should be changed so that instead of `""`, it should inform the user that the request is still in queue: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/422186b3fdd4ffb27c6e10c03755558bcf392d92#diff-1b6336f4929e7744a0cd6b0cbdbec269R446.

pg 2/632 approved b2b1449.

pg1/935 approved.
pg1/936 approved.
with npm openwhisk 2.6.0 i removed the action name parsing introduced in an earlier commit since fully qualified names are now supported.
I've reached the set of features I wanted. Opening up for (rest of) review.

i ran into this limit when using Xvfb -> gradle -> java+firefox for a selenium-based action.

as gradle builds:
```
lsof| wc -l
209
```

once firefox launches:
```
lsof| wc -l
633
```

despite the 633 number, a `ulimit -n 256` on my task seems to have lead to success (200 failed)
The shared functionality will be removed from the CLI for all commands except the package command in PR https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1499.
test case: starpit/granola on dockerhub

@domdom82  Can we verify that system limits are reasonably high (64K at least)?  Then we can raise the limits to 512.

@starpit Can you write a self-contained unit test (node action that opens N files)?
@domdom82 - Recent commit has the ansible changes we talked about.  Thanks for the input!

@rabbah. @ioana-blue, it looks like normal non-blocking action invocations will also return an HTTP status code of 202. That means I cannot rely on the HTTP status code to determine if a blocking action exceeded its limit.
That's correct.

Really like this idea @rabbah and would like to and can help directly (I have a fairly deep understanding of how deploy to bluemix (d2bm) works and its development).

The next generation of d2bm creates a devops toolchain -- see https://github.com/open-toolchain/simple-toolchain

We could create a similar "toolchain" like that quite easily for whisk but I'm wondering if creating the devops infra to deploy whisk actions, triggers, rules, etc. is overkill -- e.g. is the vision here just to deploy the runtime aspects and worry about the devops infra later?

We are currently encountering the travis build problem, the couchdb image from travis doesn't exist any more:

```
TASK [couchdb : (re)start CouchDB] *********************************************

Wednesday 30 November 2016  13:44:18 +0000 (0:00:00.077)       0:00:01.288 **** 

fatal: [172.17.0.1]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "msg": "Error pulling couchdb - code: None message: Get http://: http: no Host in request URL"}
```
Actually, it should be port 2375 since we run docker insecure (which is also a problem), port 2376 is for docker over tls.
blue PG2 644

References:
https://github.com/docker/docker-py/pull/1324
https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/issues/5774
https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/issues/5775
https://github.com/docker/docker-py/issues/501

maybe we just need to update requests 2.10.0 and the docker pull for all docker images.
But from this issue https://github.com/docker/docker-py/issues/501 it looks like ansible docker_container doesn't pull specific tags if you already have an image with a different tag already pulled.
@csantanapr good job! thank you!
couch startup fixed by https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1571
@perryibm we have to move the test to blue because the kernel in travis is too old to support the --pids-limit flag. need at least 4.3 for the flag to work which is currently unsupported in travis.
LGTM

Keep in mind that `whisk.invoke` is now deprecated as of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/85070a20f560e77ea064ebfc57f2c1eb4608f420. (In favor of npm openwhisk instead.) I defer to you whether to do this now or later.

```
    Have the controller validate that the specified API action (not the routemgmt action, but the user action) actually exists and namespace/auth has access to it before calling the routemgmt create action.
```
Fixed by #1571
@rabbah take a look at 0f2167f62e5744b3a3cb3a530182833f0b392427 I tried to address your review comments.
PG3 21

@rabbah The module relies on the user to provide the correct name format for triggers and actions.
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-client-js/blob/master/lib/rules.js#L35

I think the API change above is more consistent.

I would change the library to still allow for unqualified names and default to providing a fully-qualified name in the request using the namespace parameter. 

Let me know when this goes in and I'll work on it.
PG1 961 approved
pg2/663 approved.
pg2/664 approved.
@nwspeete-ibm can you squash all these commits and then rebase to head?

I think it's a cli bug. See output below (edited out auth and path):

```
bluewhisk/open/ansible/../bin/wsk --verbose -i --apihost 192.168.99.100 --apiversion v1 action create --auth *****  /_/sequenceWithBindingParams package2/print --sequence
exit code = 147
stdout: [/go-whisk/whisk.NewClient]:070:[Inf] Disabling certificate checking.
[mmands.parseQualifiedName]:112:[Inf] Qualified entityName: sequenceWithBindingParams
[mmands.parseQualifiedName]:113:[Inf] Qaulified namespace: _
[-cli/commands.parseAction]:477:[Inf] Parsing parameters: []string(nil)
[.getKeyValueFormattedJSON]:197:[Inf] Created key/value format '[]' from 'map[]'
[-cli/commands.parseAction]:489:[Inf] Parsing annotations: []string(nil)
[.getKeyValueFormattedJSON]:197:[Inf] Created key/value format '[]' from 'map[]'
[-cli/commands.parseAction]:624:[Inf] Parsed action struct: &whisk.Action{Namespace:"_", Name:"sequenceWithBindingParams", Version:"", Publish:false, Exec:(*whisk.Exec)(0x4208aa300), Annotations:whisk.KeyValueArr(nil), Parameters:whisk.KeyValueArr(nil), Limits:(*whisk.Limits)(nil)}
[k.(*ActionService).Insert]:153:[Inf] Action insert route: actions/sequenceWithBindingParams?overwrite=false
REQUEST:
[PUT]	https://192.168.99.100/api/v1/namespaces/_/actions/sequenceWithBindingParams?overwrite=false
Req Headers
{
  "Authorization": [
    "Basic ***********"
  ],
  "Content-Type": [
    "application/json"
  ]
}Req Body
{{"exec":{"kind":"sequence","code":"","components":["/ioana@us.ibm.com_dev/package2/print"]}}
}
[-whisk/whisk.(*Client).Do]:209:[Inf] Req Body (ASCII quoted string):
{"{\"exec\":{\"kind\":\"sequence\",\"code\":\"\",\"components\":[\"/ioana@us.ibm.com_dev/package2/print\"]}}\n"}
RESPONSE:Got response with code 403
Response body size is 103 bytes
Response body received:
{
  "error": "The supplied authentication is not authorized to access this resource.",
  "code": 1304
}
[-whisk/whisk.(*Client).Do]:233:[Inf] Response body received (ASCII quoted string):
"{\n  \"error\": \"The supplied authentication is not authorized to access this resource.\",\n  \"code\": 1304\n}"
[/whisk.parseErrorResponse]:280:[Inf] HTTP failure 403 + body
[/whisk.parseErrorResponse]:292:[Inf] HTTP failure 403; server error The supplied authentication is not authorized to access this resource. (code 1304)
[k.(*ActionService).Insert]:168:[Err] s.client.Do() error - HTTP req https://192.168.99.100/api/v1/namespaces/_/actions/sequenceWithBindingParams?overwrite=false; error 'The supplied authentication is not authorized to access this resource. (code 1304)'
[sk-cli/commands/action.go]:074:[Err] client.Actions.Insert(&whisk.Action{Namespace:"_", Name:"sequenceWithBindingParams", Version:"", Publish:false, Exec:(*whisk.Exec)(0x4208aa300), Annotations:whisk.KeyValueArr(nil), Parameters:whisk.KeyValueArr(nil), Limits:(*whisk.Limits)(nil)}, false, false) error: The supplied authentication is not authorized to access this resource. (code 1304)
[main.main                ]:066:[Inf] err object type: *whisk.WskError
[main.main                ]:070:[Err] Got a *whisk.WskError error: &whisk.WskError{RootErr:(*errors.errorString)(0x420988330), ExitCode:147, DisplayMsg:true, MsgDisplayed:false, DisplayUsage:false, ApplicationError:false}

stderr: error: Unable to create action: The supplied authentication is not authorized to access this resource. (code 1304)
```

The output above contains the cli command and the output with verbose and debug enabled. The cli is instructed to create a sequence and the component action does not have a namespace. The cli infers it as being default (i.e., `_`) and then fills it in with info from `.wskprops`:

```
Req Body
{{"exec":{"kind":"sequence","code":"","components":["/ioana@us.ibm.com_dev/package2/print"]}}
}
```

(note the namespace; it should be guest for my local run or `_`)

I can confirm that if the default namespace is explicit, the cli works properly.

If I don't have a `.wskprops` file, I can confirm that the default package is inferred as `_` by the cli. 

I'll push my changes to a branch such that this issue can be reproduced easily.

I should also say that during the same test, several other entities are created with a default namespace unspecified (i.e., `package/action`) and the cli just uses the default namespaces (i.e., `/_/package/action`). 

Not sure whether the cli behaves as designed and we may need to specify where to get a whisk properties file when using it during testing. FYI @rabbah

Branch https://github.com/ioana-blue/openwhisk/tree/ioana-issue1584 can be used to reproduce the output above. Run this test:
https://github.com/ioana-blue/openwhisk/blob/ioana-issue1584/tests/src/system/basic/WskSequenceTests.scala#L271
A side note - @paulcastro noticed on his local deployment a similar issue with rules as well.
@rabbah squashed the commits, added logging and json objects, manually tested all routes to ensure no regressions from the refactoring
@mdeuser, I left some comments on things that would be easy to fix before you merge. I will still need more time to trace through the API command code.

This is not a CLI bug (it's operating as expected/designed). The defect is in the `Wsk` scala helper - it provides an empty environment for running CLI commands but should instead override the `wskprops` file via `WSK_CONFIG_FILE=` in the `env` map.

The helper resolves all names in CLI commands to be qualified names but it looks like for sequences, these can sneak through raw.
@rabbah pointed out a couple more missing fqns. I'll fix these bugs.

Hi Guys
Thanks for the quick help.

```

skipping: [172.17.0.1]

TASK [cli : run Docker] ********************************************************

fatal: [172.17.0.1]: FAILED! => {"changed": true, "cmd": "docker run --name cli whisk/cli:latest", "delta": "0:00:03.306232", "end": "2016-12-02 21:55:17.092378", "failed": true, "rc": 125, "start": "2016-12-02 21:55:13.786146", "stderr": "Unable to find image 'whisk/cli:latest' locally\nPulling repository docker.io/whisk/cli\ndocker: Error: image whisk/cli:latest not found.\nSee 'docker run --help'.", "stdout": "", "stdout_lines": [], "warnings": []}
[FAILED]
> docker run --name cli whisk/cli:latest

Pulling repository docker.io/whisk/cli
```

Thanks
Appreciate your help.

pj
@jasonpet your comments addressed here 1d73a610cd2eddb077e48e17e5705a5ff163f536
Why is this needed for "Managing trigger feeds"? Which use-case do you have in mind specifically?

When creating a trigger using a feed like cloudant. The namespace is passed today to the feedaction when it's invoke.
That info is used to identify the trigger, to id the doc in DB, etc..
Well to identify the trigger, we might not need it anymore, but we use it to make the entry in DB unique and at the same time flexible, by not making the authkey part of the _id

I know I suggested the `fqn` on rules and sequences but note that this means we're losing test coverage (the ability to write a simple name instead of a fully qualified name); the need for the latter is replaced by the `env` override. We will need to test the CLI with the simple names as well.

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/whisk/core/cli/test/WskBasicUsageTests.scala#L475

This test reads like the CLI does not need provide the namespace to the action, cause its done by the invoker directly. The feeds might be using old legacy which we could update and thus move this use-case of the critical path of this issue?

we can provide `GET /api/v1/namespaces/_/info` to yield the name of the namespace and in the future as suggested by @markusthoemmes include quotas, current throttle limits (there may be more useful info to surface).
merged
Dropped second commit: API requires fully qualified names (note `_` is allowed for namespace in the path).
@dubeejw - Thanks for the review thus far.  The updated PR includes updates for the current comments
Thanks @dubeejw  and @mdeuser I will merge this part of the APIGW, full function will not be there but that's the plan to do it in stages.
@mdeuser lets do a PG
PG2 681 successful

@rabbah When creating the API endpoint, a target action is a required argument.  If would be nice if that action's existence and accessibility by the user credentials invoking the CLI (or REST) were validated prior to configuring the API GW with this action.
PG3 27 passed
LGTM

good finding. with the change from our own consul image to public docker hub image we did not put a custom CMD anymore, thus resulting in default CMD which is "dev" mode. see https://github.com/hashicorp/docker-consul/blob/2c2873f9d619220d1eef0bc46ec78443f55a10b5/0.X/Dockerfile

Using a custom CMD should do the trick. We wanted to use `--net=host` anyway for stability which is a long-lasting open issue.
Not now it isn't.
@markusthoemmes - any other comments?  If you agree, any outstanding nice-to-have comments will have a separate issue opened up for them.
PG1 #968 greenish
LGTM, we will handle net=host in another PR (has implications with user ns)

PG3 32
PG?
